NI has retained the Carbon Trust Standard for energy and carbon management.

Following a demanding audit process that took place in December 2012, NI was awarded recertification for the Carbon Trust Standard.

This certificate is a mark of excellence in recognition of how well we measure, manage and reduce our carbon emissions.

It is widely considered as the world-leading standard for carbon footprint certification and reduction, and provides tangible proof to company employees, shareholders, customers and suppliers that a company is committed to making future reductions.

Delighted NI Operations MD David Dinsmore said: “This is a fantastic achievement for NI. It demonstrates our firm commitment to reducing our environmental impact despite the challenging conditions that we face as a business.

“Continuing to maintain the Carbon Trust Standard provides a solid platform on which we can develop our environmental programme and build on our efforts over the coming year.”

NI initially achieved the Carbon Trust Standard in 2010 after demonstrating that our carbon footprint had fallen for three consecutive years.  Each certification period lasts for two years and to maintain certification, NI needed to demonstrate that we have continued to reduce our carbon footprint year-on-year since being originally certified.

However, the recertification process is made more challenging as the scope of the assessment is widened to include other emissions – most significantly transport from staff travel and company vehicles.

Achieving recertification is testament to the ongoing efforts of staff from across the business to reduce the company’s environmental footprint.  Through a combination of behavioural change among colleagues and investment in energy-efficient manufacturing equipment at our Newsprinters sites, we reduced our electricity consumption by approximately 13,475,000kWh between 2010 and 2012.

This is the equivalent of powering 2,450 three-bed homes for a year or keeping the Wembley Stadium arch lit for 16,818 days.

When considering all of NI’s emissions from electricity, gas and other sources, the audit showed that we have reduced our total carbon footprint by 10.4 per cent since 2010.  This has saved almost 10,500 tonnes of CO2 emissions.

To put that achievement in perspective, NI’s CO2 savings over the last two years equal 3,400 return flights for one person from London to Sydney.

As we seek to grow our business, the challenge will be to continue identifying and delivering initiatives that will further reduce our carbon footprint and environmental impact.

Reducing carbon emissions goes hand-in-hand with improving the efficiency of our business and reducing operational costs. 

If you have any questions regarding certification or want to get involved in our action on climate change, e-mail NI energy and environment manager Lugano Kapembwa on lugano.kapembwa@newsint.co.uk
Headline: Delight as NI retains Carbon Trust Standard
Intro: NI has retained the Carbon Trust Standard for energy and carbon management.

Schwarzenegger, who still works out every day, said: “I love coming back to London.”

Smart said about the new studios: “It’s all about the future for us. This is a big deal.

“We have to move on. It’s really exciting for The Sun – the next generation.

Friday, January 18, 2013


Dear Colleagues,

I am writing to update you on the latest developments regarding the leadership of our Times Titles.

Following a meeting of the Independent National Directors of The Times and The Sunday Times yesterday we welcome their clear understanding of the very difficult financial position of our newspapers and therefore the need to address the Undertakings given in 1981.  A thorough assessment of the Undertakings will enable them to make recommendations to us and to the government as to how the newspapers can be structured in order to reduce their costs and become economically viable.

However, during this period of continued consultation over the Undertakings, we have a responsibility to provide our two newspapers and journalists with strong and stable leadership.  I can therefore announce the appointment of John Witherow as temporary acting editor of The Times.  I can also announce the appointment of Martin Ivens as temporary acting editor of The Sunday Times.

Throughout John's leadership, which began in 1994, The Sunday Times has broken some of the most powerful news stories in recent years.  As one of the longest serving and the most distinguished editor on Fleet Street, John has also overseen the exponential growth in digital, delivering a market-leading world-class product that is available for customers across every platform.

Martin has a vast range of experience, serving as deputy editor of The Sunday Times since 1996 and before that enjoying a number of senior editorial roles.  I look forward to seeing him build on the progress of The Sunday Times that he has played a large part in shaping.    

Martin and John take up their new positions with immediate effect, subject to formal approval as Editors by the Independent Directors.

I am grateful for your patience, as I know there are ongoing questions and speculation surrounding the future leadership of our Times titles.  We are incredibly fortunate to have such a rich depth of talent and experience to call upon and I am confident of a long and exciting future for all our titles.

Warm regards,

KNOW YOUR ONIONS The Sun gardening editor Peter Seabrook helps Charlton Manor Primary School pupils in south-east London plant out onions

NI title The Sun is at the heart of next week’s RHS Chelsea Flower Show centenary.

As the world’s most famous horticultural event turns 100 this year, The Sun’s campaign for gardening in schools will be at the fore.

In celebration, 14,000 youngsters from 200 schools across the country pulled on their gardening gloves, growing plants and vegetables, and designing props and costumes.

The Sun is a long-standing advocate of gardening in schools and this year, to mark the centenary, each school has been given an era of gardening from the past 100 years to base their gardens around.

The NI title will be exhibiting four individual Generation Gardens to show how gardening and the plants we grow have changed over the past century.

Working alongside sponsors Miracle-Gro, The Sun sent boxes of seeds, plants and tubers for flowers, fruit and vegetables to schools across the country. Pupils from 20 of the winning schools will then man The Sun gardens in the Chelsea show Great Pavilion between May 21-25 and have their work admired by the 160,000 visitors who pass through the gates each year.

The Sun will showcase four gardens at this year’s landmark festival:

• Essex, Hertfordshire, Norfolk and Suffolk schools will cover Present Day

• London, Sussex and Kent schools are basing their gardens on Flower Power in the 1960/70s

• Greater Manchester, Cheshire, The Midlands and Northern Counties are recreating The War Years in the 1940s

• Cornwall, Devon, Dorset and Surrey schools are travelling back to the founding year of 1913.

Results from a recent survey by the Royal Horticultural Society (RHS) found that less than one per cent of parents were taught to garden while at school, compared to 55 per cent of grandparents and 40 per cent of today’s primary school children.

The Sun gardening editor Peter Seabrook said: “We have to be quick as there is an entire generation of ‘lost gardeners’. We need to encourage grandparents to pass on their gardening skills and experience to their grandchildren.

“Gardening at schools covers the whole curriculum – children need to read instructions on seed packets, write up diaries, measure plots and work out plant spacing and the benefits of school gardening range from improved behaviour to healthier eating habits.”

Blue Peter gardener Chris Collins said: “I think it’s great that The Sun is helping the next generation of gardeners grow. We are the best in the world at gardening, it is part of our heritage, and it’s great for children who are looking for different ways to learn, so it really is important that we get kids involved from an early age.”

The Sun has been committed to school gardening for more than 20 years and its campaign actively encourages more than three million children across the UK every year to get gardening.

Nursery, primary and secondary school children are taught about plants, gardening and the environment.

 


Monday, May 13, 2013
Headline: The Sun campaign grows at Chelsea Flower Show

The Times won the blue ribbon Newspaper of the Year category on a night of triumph for NI at last night's Press Awards.


NI scooped 11 gongs at the prestigious industry awards held at the Lancaster London Hotel to eclipse the previous year's haul of nine wins.

The Times also landed the News Team of the Year accolade and there was a double triumph for their writer Alexi Mostrous.

With Fay Schlesinger, he won the Scoop of the Year 2012 for their tax avoidance stories and also landed the News Reporter of the Year gong.

Accepting the Newspaper of the Year trophy, acting Times editor John Witherow said: "There is a fantastic staff at The Times as I have discovered over the past couple of months. I'd particularly like to thank James Harding, who really should be accepting this award."

The Sunday Times also enjoyed a successful evening, winning more categories than any other title with five gongs.

They were named as Sports Team of the Year and sports editor Alex Butler said he was "stunned" to receive the award. He also thanked former editor Witherow "for his support and relentless enthusiasm."

Still with Sport, Sunday Times writer David Walsh was named Sports Journalist of the Year for his doping expose of cyclist Lance Armstrong. Judges described it as “a story that left everyone else standing.” Walsh thanked his wife Mary, Witherow and Butler for their support.

In further Sunday Times triumphs, David James Smith retained his title as Broadsheet Feature Writer of the Year and Lynn Barber was selected as Broadsheet Interviewer of the Year.     

There was a standing ovation as the late Sunday Times war zone correspondent Marie Colvin was named Foreign Reporter of the Year. Colvin was killed while reporting from war-torn Syria last February.

There was also a double triumph for The Sun. Gordon Smart was chosen as Showbiz Reporter of the Year and colleague Jane Moore as Popular Columnist of the Year.

Moore said: "The Sun is the most fantastic product. A phenomenal group of journalists and I am very proud to be one of the team."

Smart was unable to attend the awards as his wife was about to give birth to their second child. He tweeted: “Proud to get a bit of silverware after six years of trying. Contractions for both Smarts here. Thanks to Bizarre team and all the great people at The Sun.”

In total, NI had 51 nominations for the awards. Apart from 11 category wins, there were also eight highly commended accolades. The awards were hosted by BBC Breakfast presenter Susanna Reid.

MASTERFUL NI’s Sati Rahman has achieved his MBA

Sati Rahman's MBA qualification also has benefits for NI.

The 5TMS-based Operations assistant production planning manager has just become a Master of Business Administration (MBA) following a study journey that began in 2000.

His merit pass culminated in a 120-page, 20,000-word dissertation on NI’s efforts to reduce carbon emissions within newspaper publishing operations.

The document is now being studied by NI. Sati even calculated that printing one tabloid page causes 0.2g of CO2 emissions.

Sati, 41, who lives in Redbridge, began the academic journey in 2000 when studying for his certificate in management.

He then took a break from study as his three children grew up – they are now 20, 17 and 15 – before returning to study for a diploma in management studies in 2009.

Helped by Operations and with a NISA bursary, Sati progressed to part-time MBA study from September 2011.

Sati, who joined NI in 1994, said: “All of the study relates to the company. It was an opportunity for me to dig deep. It was an overview of the company you could never have looked at.”

He examined aspects such as creative problem-solving, analysing change, comparative management styles between countries, strategic tools and organisational consultancy skills.

Sati, who is now involved with NI’s Staff Environment Group (SEG), then moved on to the dissertation before learning he had gained a merit grading in late February.

He said: “After studying for so many evenings and weekends, it felt like swimming across an ocean. I have so much spare time now!”

Headline: Sati is the Master

For the first time ever you can now access the intranet on the move from any location - iNI is compatible with mobile and tablet.

Below are some useful Q&As

On your first visit to the site you will be asked for your email address and password.  Once you have done this you will not be asked again unless you click on the ‘log out’ button, or you un-tick the ‘remember me’ box.

The Irish Sun has played a major role in reuniting a kidnapped eight-year-old girl with her distraught mother.

Elated mum Candice Gannon, 28, flew to Portugal on Tuesday February 12 to be reunited with her missing daughter Ellie Silva following pressure from the Irish Sun.

Ellie was missing for seven months in Portugal after being abducted by her father Felipe Silva, 35, during a holiday in his native country.

Candice struggled to make progress with the Portuguese authorities – despite an international warrant for the father’s arrest and order to return the child to the mother.

She was getting nowhere, despite months of appeals.

The Irish Sun successfully forced police and politicians in Faro on the Algarve to act after taking out a full page ad in a Portuguese newspaper.

The case was changed from a custody case to aggravated kidnap.

Irish Sun reporter Owen Conlon – who is fluent in Portuguese – was in daily contact with the family and lobbied local officials and police, until the father was arrested in a sting operation.

Candice said: "I'm so grateful for everything the Irish Sun did. I can’t express my thanks."

Irish Sun acting editor Paul Clarkson said: "This was campaigning journalism with a heart.

"Even thought it only affected one family, nothing was more important to them than the safe return of Ellie."
Headline: Irish Sun's key role to end mother's ordeal

Cyclists are set to benefit from a revolution in road safety following a four-month parliamentary inquiry, inspired by The Times Cities Fit for Cycling campaign.

A cross-party group of MPs and peers are calling for the transformation of Britain’s streets in a NI-funded report that they say will saves lives and improve public health.

The Times’ campaign was sparked after reporter Mary Bowers was severely injured when she was run over by a lorry near NI’s TMS HQ as she cycled to work in November 2011.

Mary, 28, was left fighting for life in hospital after suffering severe brain damage, a broken arm, punctured lung, broken pelvis and two broken legs.

She remains only minimally conscious, receiving round-the-clock care at a specialist nursing home in Essex.

The inquiry report, looking at how to encourage more cycling and protect those on the roads, makes the following key proposals:

• A default 20mph speed limit on residential streets

• Access for all schoolchildren to cycle training

• Better road surfaces and junctions

• Widespread segregated cycle routes

• Improved lorry design and driver training

• Stricter enforcement of road traffic law.

The inquiry report also calls for an increase in funding on cycle infrastructure to £10 a head. And it recommends a government target for increasing cycle use from the present two per cent of journeys to 10 per cent by 2025.

Prime Minister David Cameron should approve an action plan for more and safer cycling and provide leadership on an issue cutting across transport, health, planning and local government budgets, the authors of the Get Britain Cycling report say.

Above: Marie Colvin – NI donation to British Red Cross in the wake of The Sunday Times journalist’s death in Syria


A major donation by NI to support humanitarian aid to war-torn Syria has been praised by a top Red Cross official.

NI donated £100,000 to the British Red Cross Syria Crisis Appeal to help civilians caught up in violence in the wake of The Sunday Times veteran war reporter Marie Colvin being killed in the stricken Syrian city of Homs.

Colvin, 56, died a year ago on February 22 when rockets fired by the Syrian army hit a building where she was using a makeshift media centre. NI’s donation has helped Syrians in desperate need of aid through vital supplies of blankets, mattresses, tarpaulins, family hygiene parcels, family kitchen sets, surgical kits and family food parcels.

The donation has been applauded by Katy Attfield, head of disaster management at the British Red Cross.

She said: “The generous support of News International has played a significant part in helping many of the millions of people caught up in the ongoing crisis in Syria.

“As well as living in the daily shadow of violence, communities have also had to face a freezing winter; fighting to survive sub-zero temperatures and heavy snow with little shelter, fuel or warmth.

“The suffering of men, women and children has reached unprecedented levels across the country and as fighting escalates, gaining access to certain areas can be challenging.

“Nevertheless, food parcels, hygiene items, kitchen sets and blankets continue to be delivered and distributed across the country by the Syrian Arab Red Crescent (SARC) with the support of international Red Cross colleagues.”

Despite difficult and dangerous conditions, vital supplies and support now reach almost two million people per month across the country via Red Cross and Red Crescent staff and volunteers.  First aid expertise and ambulance support are among some of the key ways in which SARC has been providing help on the ground since 2011.



Above: Ambulance support is a vital element of providing aid in crisis-hit Syria


SARC volunteer ambulance driver Hamza described his life-saving work during fighting at the Yarmouk refugee camp in December. Hamza was called to help people in need of treatment at the camp in Damascus, where violence had left its hospitals completely overwhelmed and unable to take in all of the injured. The 22-year-old student spent the day taking casualties for urgent treatment outside the camp before eventually returning to base, washing the blood from his ambulance – and heading back to Yarmouk the next day.

He said: “My first case was an 18-year-old man who had been shot in the head.

We stabilised him as best as we could and then decided to take him to Mushtahid Hospital where they have specialist support. On the way, we administered CPR and tried to prevent his condition deteriorating any further.”

The teenager was among seven injured people stabilised and transported to hospital by SARC for further treatment that day.

Across Syria, millions of people have been displaced from their homes or fled the country. Lives and livelihoods are being disrupted, and in many places access to healthcare, and food, water and other basic supplies is still difficult.

To date, the British Red Cross has provided more than £5million in aid from donations including those to its emergency appeal.

As well as food parcels and other aid items, the Red Cross/Red Crescent Movement is bringing medical supplies and working to get water supplies to places where displaced people are living. SARC is also running clinics and an emergency ambulance service.

Serena Kutchinsky (above), talks about her work as Digital Editor of the Sunday Times Magazine:


Why did you decide to go into journalism?
I read history at Oxford then went to City University to do their Postgraduate course in newspaper journalism, which gave me a fantastic grounding and helped me form valuable industry contacts. I have worked across print and digital in my career, and luckily started out when there were just beginning to be good opportunities for young journalists in digital.

What do you enjoy most about being a journalist?
I’m sure everyone will say the diversity but its true, no one day is ever the same. I also love the fact you get to meet so many interesting people, whether they are celebrities or not, they all have a fascinating story to tell. Usually the people who want to be journalists are the type of people who are confident talking to strangers and enjoy the art of conversation.

Best scoop?
I've worked on so many great stories over my time at The Sunday Times, one lasting memory is flying to Copenhagen to interview John Cleese and film part of his last tour long before it opened in Britain. The video footage was syndicated many times over. I was also lucky enough to get a tour of Disney's incredible archives in Los Angeles. We persuaded them to allow us to do our own filming inside which was a first. I'm also proud of the story I'm working on at the moment for The Sunday Times Magazine.

What do you think will be the big social media trends of 2013?
Instagram was the big tech story of last year and it's still evolving. Twitter has just launched a new app called Vine which allows users to embed six seconds of video in Tweets. It's obviously a tiny amount of footage but it's already created a lot of buzz and it fits well within Twitter's micro-blogging ethos.

How has social media changed journalism?
Journalists are more accountable and accessible to their readers especially as a result of sites such as Twitter, which is a huge change with both positive and negative impacts. Readers are now used to sharing content across social networks and having lively and informed discussions with friends around the world. Journalists also use social networks as a source of information, although we are still aware of the need to fact check anything we find on there. It's hard to summarise as I think we are still seeing the impact on journalism around the globe.

What’s been your favourite story of 2013 so far?
I’m paying close attention to the Europe debate, but the big serious story at the moment is the Algeria hostage situation, which shows how the focus on terrorism is shifting to North Africa. It’s ironic that this terrible crisis is going on the same week that the film Zero Dark Thirty, which chronicles the decade long hunt for Osama Bin Laden and the fight against terrorism in the Middle East, is hitting the cinemas. I think that is definitely the story to watch at the moment

From Ben Webster, Media Editor, The Times, in today's edition (Wednesday, May 1, 2013)



Politicians should not be given the final say on any changes to a new system of press regulation, according to an opinion poll commissioned by the newspaper industry. Most people also believe there should be a consultation on the proposed Royal Charter on press regulation before it is submitted to the Queen for her signature.

A group of newspaper publishers last week rejected a charter endorsed by the three main parties and the Hacked Off campaign. The publishers, which include News International, owner of The Times, The Sunday Times and The Sun, and four other national newspaper groups, have produced a rival charter that they say has important differences to protect the freedom of the press.

The poll, commissioned by the Free Speech Network, which is led by newspaper publishers, found that 67 per cent said the new system of press regulation should be set up “in a way that does not give politicians the final say if and when changes need to be made”.

Under the politicians’ charter, changes could be made only if supported by two-thirds majorities in both Houses of Parliament. The publishers’ version would not give politicians any say and would require changes to be approved unanimously by industry trade associations, the board of a new regulator and a separate “recognition panel”.

Three quarters of adults (76 per cent) said there should be a consultation on the charter to allow the public their say, as the publishers propose for their version. Only 12 per cent said there was no need for a consultation if a charter had been approved by politicians.

The Government has resisted calls to have a public consultation on the draft charter it published on March 18, hours after it was approved by the three main parties in the presence of four Hacked Off representatives in the office of Ed Miliband, Labour’s leader.

The poll, for which Survation questioned 1,000 adults, also found that a small majority (53 per cent) was willing to wait up to a year for a new system of press regulation to be introduced. The overwhelming majority did want a new system of regulation.

The politicians’ charter is also being challenged by the Chartered Institute of Journalists, which has written to the Privy Council expressing concern that it could conflict with its charter granted by Queen Victoria in 1890.

Charlie Harris, president of the institute, which has 1,700 members, said: “We have legal advice that the [Government’s] charter ... has serious implications for our own charter.”

The Department for Culture, Media and Sport said that it had not yet submitted the politicians’ charter to the Privy Council. It is unclear whether the Government will proceed with its plan to ask the Queen to sign it at the Privy Council meeting scheduled for May 15.

Several senior Conservatives, including Peter Lilley, have called for a delay to allow the publishers’ version to be considered.

In its guidelines on applying for Royal Charters, the Privy Council says: “Any proposal which is rendered controversial by a counter-petition is unlikely to succeed.”

News International’s new ABC Awards got off to a rip-roaring start thanks to music legends The Rolling Stones.

The Above and Beyond the Call (ABC) staff appreciation awards were launched on November 1 with the opportunity to nominate colleagues to win a pair of tickets to see supergroup the Stones celebrate their 50-year career with a special gig at London’s O2 arena on November 25.

The winners, nominated by colleagues, were: James Attwater, Commercial, Manchester; Claire Gorman, The Sun, Dublin; Mark Hayman, The Sun Fabulous magazine; Sophie Holland, Technology, London; Iain King, Scottish Sun; Dan Leonard, The Times; Danny Sharples, Commercial, London; John Salmon, The Sunday Times and Wayne Thorpe, Newsprinters Knowsley.

Business analyst Sophie said: “It was such a lovely surprise to win tickets to see The Rolling Stones, I felt really valued at News International.

“We were so well-treated in the box, served hot food and drinks all evening, and I took my dad along – who really appreciated it!

“The gig was electric, the band were so wrinkly and yet amazingly had more energy than me (in my twenties), always running around and owning the stage, and never looking remotely tired.

“The highlights for me were Paint It Black (really stunning) and the encore of You Can’t Always Get What You Want. The sound quality and view was great.”

Claire commented: “Winning the tickets to see The Rolling Stones came as a huge surprise.

“The whole experience from start to finish – the cable car to the O2, the box, the show – was breathtaking.

“My friend and I were treated like VIPs in the News International suite – delicious food, perfect seats – and it was great to meet and chat to the other winners.

“The band pulled out all the stops for the show. I now understand all the hype about Mick Jagger’s moves. I can’t believe the man is almost 70.

“It was the experience of a lifetime and one I’ll never forget.”

John remarked: “To be one of the winners of this award was truly unexpected. Even now, after the gig, I can’t quite believe that I was chosen or that my colleagues nominated me in the first place.

“The box at the O2 was brilliant, complemented by a steady flow of refreshments and food.

“Having never seen The Rolling Stones, I felt very privileged to get what is now a very rare chance to do so, and they were brilliant. Any fears that these ageing rockers were past it were put to rest from the very start and they continued to thrill throughout.

“I just want to say thank you very much to the ABC Awards and to my colleagues for giving me this opportunity to have such a great night watching one of the world’s biggest bands.”

Danny from Commercial said: “Thank you NI, what an amazing prize. Tickets aside, recognition for my work is fantastic, but the fact that this appreciation materialised in the form of two Stones tickets…unbelievable.

“The boys have still got it! At the tender age of 23, I doubt even I could ‘move like Jagger’ still can, in fact I fear for the welfare of his joints. So energetic was the performance that I needed a sit down – luckily there was a private suite on hand. I could definitely get used to this.”

The ABC Awards incorporate Spot Prizes and Money Can’t Buy accolades.

Spot Prizes are awarded throughout the year by executive directors and editors to recognise exceptional work. These will include Amazon vouchers and tickets to events at the O2 and Wembley.

Money Can’t Buy quarterly prizes are for nominated colleagues for consistently going the extra mile. These include tickets to film premieres, football/rugby internationals, The Ashes, Wimbledon and other fantastic events.

Rebecca Heryett, compensation and benefits manager in HR at TMS, won a Spot Prize to see Robbie Williams at the O2.

She said: “Wow what an evening, a fab night was had by all at the Robbie concert. The show was high-energy with classic singalong tunes intermingled with his new songs to make for a great night.

“I also got to meet some great people from across the business and would definitely advocate the ABC Awards – thanks NI, it was a top night.”

Marketing events manager Amy Dawson was also chosen to see Williams.

She said: “I was extremely excited and grateful when I won the tickets. It was out of the blue and I was very flattered to have been chosen. The fact it was Robbie was ideal as I saw him at Knebworth a few years ago and loved it.

“The box was brilliant, the people that went were great and we had such a laugh. We had a great view and Robbie is the ultimate entertainer so he was fantastic. I thoroughly enjoyed my evening and it was a great way to meet people in other areas of NI that I don’t get to interact with in my day-to-day role.”

NI cross-country ace Frank Tickner is celebrating a double British title triumph.

On Saturday March 9, TMS-based Enterprise product manager Tickner won the McCain Cross Challenge Series final that incorporated the Inter-Counties Championship held at Cofton Park in Birmingham.

Victory in the midlands mud saw 29-year-old Frank retain his McCain crown and land the Inter-Counties title for the second time.

As the race also served as a trial for the World Cross-Country Championships, Ticknerhas been selected for the global event at Bydgoszcz in Poland on Sunday March 24.

GB runner Tickner, who gets married this year, received a £2,000 prize for the McCain Series win.

Tickner, who was tied in the standings with rival Andy Vernon before the Birmingham final, said: “It went as well as it could. I went out as hard as possible to take the sting out of Andy’s kick later on.”

He led from start to finish to win the senior men’s 12km race in 33mins 54secs.

Steve Vernon crossed the line in second place (34:05), with 2011 winner Andy Vernon finishing six seconds behind his namesake to complete the podium positions.

Tickner got off to a strong start with Steve Vernon, Jonathan Taylor and Mike Skinner forming a breakaway group after six kilometres with Andy Vernon, returning from an Achilles injury, leading the charge to bridge the gap on the leading four athletes.

With five kilometres to go, Tickner and Steve Vernon increased their advantage, with Taylor and Skinner unable to match the burst from the leading duo. Andy Vernon continued to move up the field, catching Taylor and Skinner to move up into third place and a podium spot.

Tickner continued to assert his dominance in the closing stages, moving away from Steve Vernon to open up a considerable lead going into the last three kilometres. He extended his advantage further with the finish line in his sights.  

TIckner was delighted with both the victory on the day and the overall series prize.

He said: “I’m very pleased, I can’t say I expected it. It was a tough way to have done it but it was nice to have beaten some of the guys that were there at the National because I wasn’t there. It was nice to get into a race where most of the key figures are there.

“The win took over my thoughts but I’m really pleased to have won the overall series, that’s the cherry on the cake really.

“I’m quite keen to try out a half-marathon later on and make the most of the miles in my legs.”

I wanted to let you know that today we have joined the overwhelming majority of the newspaper and magazine industry in applying for an independent Royal Charter to establish a tough new system of press self-regulation.

We believe that this independent Royal Charter will deliver the tough, yet voluntary system of self-regulation envisaged by Lord Justice Leveson, but crucially without leaving the press at the mercy of the politicians we hold to account.

At News International our journalism is robust, but we are also responsible.  We have already taken considerable steps to address past mistakes, and we are determined to play our part in restoring public confidence in our industry.

All the best,

Andrew Norfolk, chief investigative reporter for The Times, has landed a major journalism award.

Yesterday (February 26), Norfolk scooped the Paul Foot Award for Investigative and Campaigning Journalism for his two-year investigation into the targeting, grooming and sexual exploitation of teenage girls by gangs of men.

The prestigious awards, with a £5,000 top prize, were set up by Private Eye and the Guardian in memory of the campaigning journalist Paul Foot who died in 2004.

Private Eye editor Ian Hislop said: “The Foot awards this year are a powerful post-Leveson riposte to all those who want to think only the worst of journalists. The shortlist celebrates those whose great skill is to make the public really interested in what is really in the public interest.”

Norfolk’s investigation prompted two Government-ordered inquiries, a parliamentary inquiry and a new national action plan on child sexual exploitation.

Judges said: “The investigation revealed a crime model that police and care agencies refused to recognise – that most of the victims were white and a majority of those in identified abuse networks were men of Pakistani origin.

“Andrew Norfolk’s powerful articles revealed how the reluctance of agencies to acknowledge and confront a widespread form of abuse in deprived northern communities had broken families and shattered the lives of some of society’s most vulnerable children.

“Andrew Norfolk’s reports consistently ran throughout last year, exposing past failures to protect children and prosecute offenders – when detailed intelligence was held about victims and perpetrators. The campaign has been instrumental in forcing all concerned with the protection of children to give a higher priority to cases of sexual exploitation.”

Other NI journalists were also shortlisted, with finalists receiving a £1,000 prize. They were: Alexi Mostrous and Fay Schesinger of The Times for ‘Secrets of the tax avoiders’ and Jonathan Calvert and Heidi Blake from The Sunday Times with ‘Generals for hire’.

Lynn Barber won the Press Award for ‘Interviewer of the Year’ for the sixth time in 2012. Here she talks about her illustrious career, interviewing and getting under the skin of a long line of famous and infamous people.

Lynn Barber started out writing children’s stories for her local paper, The Richmond and Twickenham Times, while she was still at school, and when studying English at Oxford she wrote for student papers Cherwell and Isis. Her professional career began at Penthouse magazine in 1966. However since then she has written for many different British newspapers and for the American magazine Vanity Fair. She has published two collections of her interviews ‘Mostly Men’ and ‘Demon Barber’. Her memoir, ‘An Education’, was made into a BAFTA-winning film starring Carey Mulligan in 2009. Her next book, ‘My Life in Interviews’, is due out next year. She joined The Sunday Times in 2009.

What do you think was your most important or revealing interview and why?

I don’t know if it was ‘important’ but I did a highly controversial interview with the tennis player Rafael Nadal in 2011 which means I have been trolled by Rafa fans ever since! I didn’t find him as charming as everyone told me I would. But I took the opportunity to point out that sports stars are now so tightly controlled by PRs we really have no idea of their true characters.

An interview that has returned to haunt me is one I did with Sir Jimmy Savile in 1990. It caused great scandal at the time because he had just been knighted and he was showing me all the telegrams of congratulation he’d had from members of the royal family. And then I told him there was a very widespread rumour that he liked little girls. It obviously didn’t come as news to him, and he had a pat answer, but readers were shocked that I even raised the question. The general assumption was that he would not have been knighted if there were any suspicions about him – we now know of course that that is not true.

What factor has contributed most to your enduring career in journalism?

I think what’s kept me going as an interviewer is my enduring nosiness. I have never lost my curiosity about other people or my desire to try to understand their lives.  It probably stems from being an only child and wondering what other families were like. I believe, as I said in my memoir, An Education, that other people are ultimately unknowable – but that’s what makes the pursuit so interesting.

I also made a wise decision early on to interview as wide a range of people as possible – everyone from Harriet Harman to Lady Gaga – so that I could not be typecast as either a heavyweight or lightweight interviewer. The only people I don’t like interviewing are very nice, friendly, straightforward people with no hang-ups. I am much happier interviewing people who are rude, difficult, and abrasive – give me a Lord Sugar over a Michael Palin every time.

Is there anyone, a major world figure perhaps, you would like to interview and why?

I would LOVE to interview Rupert Murdoch! I would also like to interview Bill Clinton, Tony Blair, Mick Jagger and/or Keith Richards. I spent years trying to get an interview with the artist Lucian Freud, writing to him about once a month, and was eventually rewarded with a hand-written note saying he did not wish ‘to be shat on by a stranger’ – I now have it framed in my loo. But I never got an interview.

What does winning Interviewer of the Year at the press awards mean to you?

I was thrilled to win my sixth Press Award this year, having won my first in 1986 – I can now boast that I’ve been winning Press Awards for four decades! What’s great about the Press Awards is that they’re given by journalists to journalists so they really are the Oscars of our profession.

Headline: In conversation with Lynn Barber

Tuesday, April 30, 2013


Dear Colleagues,

We now have the results of the Your Opinion survey that was completed in February.  An impressive 88% of you took the time to tell the executive team and me how you feel about working at News International.  Thank you.

When we launched the survey, we made a commitment to listen to what you are saying and act on the key areas you highlight.  We also promised to share the results with everyone around the business.

For the first time ever, we have made the results of the survey available for every member of staff – please click here.  We have already shared the results with senior managers across the business and they will be speaking with you about the results and what they mean for your department in the coming weeks.

Derrick Crowley, NI’s Group HR Director, will be hosting a webchat at 1:30pm on Thursday, May 2, to take you through the results and answer your questions. More details on this will follow shortly.

For me, the strongest message that has come out of the survey is the appetite for a clear strategy and sense of direction for NI.  This is not a surprise and has been my priority for the past three and a half months. I have been working closely with the executive team and we are a few weeks away from starting to set out in detail what the ‘NI story’ will mean for all of us.

The survey reveals a strong belief in the world-class quality of our content and your pride in our products.  It also tells us that many of you are feeling less confident and optimistic about the future.  This is understandable given the very difficult period the company has been through and is further evidence of the need for a coherent and straightforward vision.

It is clear that we need to get better at linking our future to yours. Some areas of the business are much better than others at helping people to plan their careers and get access to training and development; we want to make sure this is consistently accessible in every department.  There is also a demand for increased communication and we will be building on recent improvements to ensure you are kept informed of the company’s direction.

Our day-to-day operation is working well in many areas.  People understand their roles and how they are contributing to the success of their department and the company.  There is a great affinity within teams and a high level of support between colleagues, for which I am very grateful.  Successful teamwork and collaboration are an essential part of our success, both now and in the future.

These are some initial thoughts and I welcome your input as you discuss these results in teams over the coming weeks.  Please do take the time to watch the webchat with Derrick on Thursday where he will be covering the survey in more detail and answering your questions.

Warm regards,

Friday, January 25, 2013

Dear Colleagues,

I would personally like to thank all those involved in distributing our papers during the recent challenging weather conditions.  A great many of you put in a tremendous effort to ensure we reached our customers in the face of considerable disruption.  

As I have been saying during my ongoing visits around the business, it is right that we take pride in NI - in our people and papers and also in the way in which we produce and deliver our titles.

The extent of the work that often goes unseen has been eye-opening for me and is truly impressive.  Our Direct to Customer (DTC) operation delivers to 9,000 homes Mon-Sat and 16,000 on a Sunday.  Every night of the week 150 drivers reach 6,000 retailers within the M25 and over 100 vehicles leave our print sites for depots which then distribute our titles to 48,000 retailers located the length and breadth of the UK and Ireland.

It is a testament to the dedication across all levels of our business that, even during the worst conditions, 99.7% of DTC deliveries were error-free - one of our drivers even finished his route in a cab when his own car broke down.

Supplies to supermarkets on Thursday of last week were increased significantly in anticipation of additional footfall preceding the severe weather.  This foresight generated increased sales in these outlets of approximately 9% for The Sun and 22% for The Times.  And on Friday, January 18 - a day with fewer people travelling - the astute re-allocation of our titles to local convenience stores generated increased sales of approximately 9% for The Sun and 15% for The Times.

These are just a few examples that demonstrate a high degree of professionalism and dedication, as well as excellent collaboration and communication across teams, turning difficult circumstances into successful opportunities. 
 
Warm regards,

This week The Times launched its inaugural Web List, a daily list of the 50 best websites chosen by experts, including celebrities such as pop star Will.i.am, digital guru Martha Lane Fox, property expert Kirsty Allsopp, Tony Blair’s former spin doctor Alastair Campbell, celebrity chef Gordon Ramsay and billionaire entrepreneur Richard Branson.

The Sunday Times also published part one of its annual best 500 App List, featuring the most useful, entertaining and weirdest apps on the planet.  The list is broken down over a number of different categories, including arts, business, education, fashion, food and drink, gadgets, news, games, music, shopping, sport, travel and the age-old favourite British subject, weather.

With the phenomenal rise of smartphones and portable devices, apps have become a way of life for millions of people. Apple users alone downloaded nearly 20 billion apps last year, which is the equivalent of almost three for every person on Earth, and the app boom is set to continue in 2013.  Part two will feature this coming Sunday, February 3.

Apps to make the grade this year include: LivingSocial, Great British Chefs, Nigellissima, Malcolm Tucker: the Missing Phone, The Rolling Stones Official App, James May Science Stories and Robots for iPad. Hundreds more have impressed the panel, including both Grand Theft Auto: Vice City and AA Drivesafe, which reward very different styles of driving.

The list also illustrates trends in the app world such as the rise of apps that save you money and the growth of ‘freemium’ apps, which don't charge for the basic app but then sell extra content at a price. Apps that charge more but offer high production values and superb photography or illustrations are also becoming highly sought after.

More than half the apps have never appeared in the list before, showing the rapidly changing market and demand for bigger, better and more sophisticated products.

In addition to the App List, the inaugural Web List appears each day this week in The Times, providing the essential address book for modern life.

The Web List kicked off on Saturday with the ‘Top Websites You Can't Live Without’, which included temporary email generator 10minutemail.com, theswizzle.com that helps people unsubscribe from emails and digitaltheatre.com, which enables theatre to be watched online. Plus, the list provides the best health websites, such as qintervention.org, which gives information about whether someone’s lifestyle choices might lead to a heart attack or stroke and how best to lower the risk.

NI's CEO Mike Darcey explains why he supports the Bristol Area Kidney Patients Association through the Give As You Earn Scheme.

"I am supporting BAKPA because of close family links.  My brother-in-law, Tony, suffered kidney problems at the age of 7 and was given 5-10 years to live.  At that time dialysis treatment was new.  At the age of 14, when his kidneys failed completely, he was given the chance of life through dialysis on a kidney machine, 3 times a week for 14 hours at a time.  He later had one failed kidney transplant and then one successful transplant in his twenties".  

"My father-in-law, Tony's father, helped set up the predecessor of BAKPA to provide support to patients and their families struggling with renal failure.  Tony's transplanted kidney eventually failed a few years ago, and so he returned to requiring dialysis 3 times a week.  Tony died earlier this year, aged 56, as a result of the side effects of all the medical treatment through his life.  This was a very sad time for the family, but Tony had far more life than the doctors originally projected and the BAKPA grew out of his life and will continue to help afflicted families, support the work of dialysis units and their staff, and raise the profile of kidney research and transplantation".

In an informal event organised for media correspondents and journalists from across the industry last night (Mar 26), Mike Darcey confirmed plans to begin charging for The Sun’s online offering.

During the Q&A session on the 13th floor of 3TMS, Mike confirmed that The Sun will start charging for its online content later this year, taking advantage of the momentum provided by the recent purchase of the Premier League clips rights.  He described the current situation - in which we ask 2.3m people to pay for The Sun newspaper each day while others get all of The Sun's online content for free - as 'untenable’.
 
He outlined his views for how the industry can adapt and prosper in a market that is continually evolving.  He also reiterated NI’s commitment to the ‘pay model’ for the news business and his assertion that NI produces news and analysis that is worth paying for.

Mike spoke of NI being ‘a very different company’ from the one which filled the headlines nearly two years ago for all the wrong reasons, covering the measures that have been introduced to enable the company to focus on the future.

In an industry that is facing a number of pressures, he outlined the fact that more than 20 million people in the UK read a national newspaper every week - and news is not going out of fashion anytime soon.

Drawing upon his previous experience at Sky, there are also lessons we can learn from pay-TV and other media, offering paid-for quality content against the backdrop of a free proposition. The paid-for TV journey started out in an environment where the concept of paying extra for TV was considered almost ludicrous, and is now a multi-billion pound industry.

NI has invested a great deal in our journalism and will continue to do so in order to breathe new life into the industry and create an environment where our titles can thrive.

Dear Colleagues,

Overnight in New York, News Corporation announced its third quarter earnings for FY13.  Overall the company recorded healthy financial results for Q3 FY13, with year on year revenue for the quarter up 14% to $9.54 billion and adjusted operating income up 4% to $1.43 billion.

Regarding the publishing part of the business, News Corporation reported quarterly segment operating income of $85 million, a $45 million decrease from the $130 million reported in the same period a year ago.  Within these results, the UK newspapers’ contribution increased, benefiting from the launch of the Sunday edition of The Sun in February 2012.  This was more than offset by lower advertising revenues at the Australian newspapers and integrated marketing services businesses.  Amplify, the Company’s education business, continued its investment phase working towards the aim of transforming the education market, considered as the last business to be touched by the digital revolution.

Commenting on the results, Rupert Murdoch said:

“We are on target to complete the proposed separation of our businesses near the end of our fiscal year.  As we prepare to launch two new industry leaders with new News Corporation and 21st Century Fox, I am more confident than ever of the long-term value the separation will unlock for the Company and its shareholders.” 

At NI we will be starting out life in the new business in a fantastic position, able to draw on a rich heritage, a strong stable of brands and cutting edge technology – helping us continue to deliver our distinctive editorial content and build a profitable future.
 
There will be more details communicated around the formation of the new company in the coming weeks, and we will also be sharing with you the comprehensive vision and strategy for NI that has been my priority since I joined in January.

The Sun has teamed up with Wimbledon-based press agency Sportsbeat to offer a 40-week scholarship worth £7,500 to a resident of one of London’s six Olympic Boroughs.

Starting in September, the placement is accredited by the National Council for the Training of Journalists (NCTJ) and will include one day a week on The Sun's sportsdesk.  If the successful candidate passes all their exams, they will be offered a six-week paid internship with Sportsbeat followed by a three-month paid internship with SunSport.

The SunSport Diversity in Journalism Scholarship aims to build on the Olympic legacy by providing a life-changing opportunity to a budding journalist who has been put off from trying to become a journalist because of concerns over college fees.

Any resident from Hackney, Barking and Dagenham, Greenwich, Tower Hamlets, Newham or Waltham Forest can apply.

A judging panel made up of journalists from The Sun and Sportsbeat will be looking for candidates who can demonstrate they have the potential to make a great journalist as well as explaining how their background would bring diversity into the newsroom. Applicants must have a minimum of two A-levels or equivalent.

The Sun editor Dominic Mohan said: “We are delighted to be involved in this project which offers an excellent journalistic opportunity and builds on the London 2012 Olympic legacy.”

Former Arsenal and England soccer star Ian Wright, now a regular sports columnist for The Sun, said: “What a brilliant opportunity for someone to get into the media covering sport. It’s exciting that people who would not normally consider this a career option now have the chance to go for it.”

Sportsbeat editor David Parsons said: “Our aim is to teach and inspire the reporting stars of tomorrow and for four straight years our trainees have made our sister company, News Associates, the number one ranked NCTJ journalism school in London.

“We are also excited at having a driven and ambitious young reporter supplementing our agency's work throughout their nine months studying on our training scheme. There will certainly be plenty of opportunities to work at sporting venues across the country and assist our journalists reporting on the build-up to the 2014 Commonwealth Games.”

The course includes modules in news reporting and sports journalism, video journalism and shorthand, as well as sports PR, media law and public affairs. Four days a week will be spent at a training centre in South-West London and there will be an opportunity to contribute to Sportsbeat’s network of football and rugby union reporting.

Bob Satchwell, Executive Director of the Society of Editors, said:  “Any scheme that opens the doors to a career in journalism to those who might normally be priced out of a college place is very good news.

“This is a great opportunity for somebody to embark on a career and I congratulate The Sun and Sportsbeat for the initiative that complements the important work of the Journalism Diversity Fund that is administered on behalf of the media by the NCTJ.”

Joanne Butcher, Chief Executive of the National Council for the Training of Journalists, said: “This scholarship is a wonderful idea which will give someone an opportunity to break into the exciting world of sports journalism while experiencing at first-hand how the sports desk of a national newspaper works.
 
“I welcome the initiative by The Sun and Sportsbeat to help widen the diversity of journalism trainees.”

The application process opens on February 1, 2013 with a deadline of April 30, 2013. Application forms are available by emailing sunscholarship@sportsbeat.co.uk.

Fabulous magazine today celebrates five years being at the top of its game.

The Sun supplement launched on February 4, 2008 with Kelly Osbourne as cover girl. The title replaced Sunday magazine as News of the World's women's magazine and has since been housed by three different newspapers, most recently in The Sun on Sundays.

In five years Fabulous has lured a raft of A-list names onto it's iconic covers. Lady Gaga, Simon Cowell, J-Lo, One Direction and Cheryl Cole have all graced page one and helped Fabulous become Britain's most-read women's glossy magazine.

The title has won numerous awards, with its editor Rachel Richardson being named Editor of the Year (Newspaper and Current Affairs Magazines) at the 2012 BSME awards, whilst Assistant Editor (Celebrity) Beth Neil won Interviewer of the Year at last year's British Press Awards.

Editor, Rachel Richardson said: "Fabulous has enjoyed huge success over the last five years and I'm thrilled we have reached this milestone and remain the market leader.

"Given the closure of News of the World, it is even more amazing that we are able to celebrate our anniversary in The Sun.

"My team and I have exciting plans to develop the brand and evolve the magazine in 2013, so we are hoping our sixth year is as successful as the last five."



A Fabulous journey

Amid a blaze of publicity, Fabulous magazine began life as the News of the World mag on February 3, 2008.  Following the closure of the NotW in July 2011, Fabulous switched to the Saturday edition of sister title The Sun. When the Sunday edition of the Sun was launched a year ago, Fabulous became part of that new era.
An eventful five-year journey, but the magazine has gone from strength to strength. Here, Fabulous editor Rachel Richardson (pictured above) answers our questions about the magazine.


How has Fabulous overcome the challenges of changing title and publication day?
The closure of News of the World was very tough for my team. Not only did the Fabulous staff believe they had lost their jobs for a few hours, they watched all of their colleagues lose theirs. It was a very sad time. Thankfully for the Fabulous team the decision was taken to re-home the magazine on Saturday's in The Sun. I think the magazine has flourished under The Sun and being back on a Sunday feels right as we are an indulgent and inspirational read. Saturday's were fun, but Sunday's are where we belong.


What are the key areas that Fabulous has developed in over the past five years?
The overall package has become much slicker as we have found our feet and confidence. We have launched and succeed in producing great campaigns and talked-about features. Visually it is a much more appealing magazine than it was for its first issues. I am really proud of our success in making Fabulous a brand in its own right, which has spawned successful extensions like Fabulous Bingo, the Fabulous Fashion Awards and the Fabulous Beauty Awards. We have also made huge strides digitally. The Fabulousmag.co.uk site, which was relaunched last May, has it's own identity and is growing in terms of unique users and page views each month.
The magazine has won numerous awards. That must be tribute to a talented staff.

Fabulous has been given various honours at BSME and the British Press Awards and I feel they have been in recognition of my hugely talented team. I am very lucky to have great strength in depth, so from my fashion team to the subs desk they are all at the top of their game. I have a great leadership team and an outstanding Creative Director in Mark Hayman. Assistant Editor (Celebrity) Beth Neil is an exceptional journalist who procures and writes up to 53 cover stories a year. No one else in the business has that pressure. And the picture team deserve a mention for their brilliant work making our covers so iconic week in week out.  


How important is developing the Fabulous digital presence?
It is hugely important to us to have a Fabulous digital presence. Producing the best possible Fabulous is often restricted by our pagination and regularity. Digitally we are free of those chains and can deliver Fabulous to audiences beyond readers of The Sun.


You must be delighted at the calibre of star interviews/photo-shoots Fabulous has managed to attract.
Fabulous has been able to attract world famous celebrities with ease because we can provide celebrities with a huge audience and we always shoot them in a creative way.  In a highly competitive market we are often selected to get the exclusive, from Justin Bieber's only UK interview to promote his album, to One Direction's first interview in 9 months, we are able to bring our readers the hot star that week. I'm particularly proud that we interviewed and shot Lady Gaga exclusively for the magazine, that we can get access to Jennifer Lopez and that the Kardashians will shoot for us.  We are also able to attract world-class photographers to shoot for us. Not many tabloid supplements can boast about that.

What is your favourite front cover?
I think on reflection Lady Gaga was a real coup. Most recently I adore our six-cover special with One Direction, while our beauty special with Katherine Jenkins was a exceptional. I'm a huge fan of our Tom Daly one too. The team had just an 1 hour to shoot a cover and inside pictures, yet produced a stunning set of images that Tom himself picked for his official calendar.


What of the future for Fabulous?
Fabulous has a very exciting future. We have just undertaken some extensive reader research and new plans will be born out of that. We are also hoping to develop the male-female double issue concept which we trialled in November. One half of the magazine was Fabulous content and the other MF content (Men's Fabulous) Expect to see a few more of them in 2013, as well as some exciting digital developments.

Featured Article: Our Future by Mike Darcey

New NI CEO Mike Darcey talks about the role and his vision for the company’s future. The former BSkyB chief operating officer took over at the start of the year and began introductory visits around the business with talks in The Sun, The Times and The Sunday Times’ newsrooms on January 8.


What’s your ambition at NI?
I will work hard to be the CEO the company deserves, bringing out the best in our people and putting the business on a sound footing for the future.

Does that mean making money?
In large part, yes. Every area of this business should be sustainably profitable in the future. I don’t want us to be subsidised by the Americans or Australians, and I don’t want us to be the sick child of the new company we’ll become part of this summer.

How will you achieve that?
I want to invest in our journalism, and focus very sharply on our readers. Putting the customer first is key. We need to lock in more of our readers through subscriptions, and ensure that when we do they are getting value – and stick with us.

Will you stick with the paywall?
Absolutely. I don’t like the name, but I believe in the principle. I’d call it “news worth paying for”. We charge for our content because we spend good money on it. You can’t invest in quality journalism and give it away.

But others do?
Yes, and I know from my previous role how hard it is to compete with a free rival, and see off the parasites who profit from simply re-packaging material some of us spent good money producing.

What is your plan for the papers?
I have no intention of breathing down editorial necks. We have first-class journalists on all our titles.  My role is to run the business, not edit those titles.

Is there a future for print?
There certainly is. News is a basic human necessity. We should provide it any time, any place and on the full range of available platforms. Print is one of those platforms, and will co-exist alongside digital for some time yet.

How can we park the past?
We have to acknowledge the past, but then focus on the future. And then ensure that our pride in our papers is matched by a pride in how we go about our business. We all need to do the training on offer, but this is ultimately about culture not just rules.  Imagine if we were profiled on the Ten O’Clock News. I’d like to ensure we could stand up to that scrutiny in our stride.

 

MIKE DARCEY PROFILE

Born: June 10, 1965

Age: 47

Family: Wife Julie, son Jonathan (16) and daughter Laura (14)

Lives at: Teddington in West London

Supports: Chelsea at football (his children were born at Chelsea Hospital so he has inherited this from his kids) and The All Blacks at rugby

Favourite food: Anything from south-east Asia, loves spicy food

Music: ‘Dad rock’ from Pink Floyd and Led Zeppelin, to more modern bands like Kings of Leon, The Vaccines, The Script, Band of Skulls

Book: Wolf Hall and Bring up the Bodies by Hilary Mantel

TV show: Homeland

Places: Beaches and mountains. He particularly likes Woolacombe Bay in Devon; surfing at Whitesands Bay in Pembrokeshire and walking in the Lake District. Also, anywhere where there is lots of snow and a steep slope

Charities: Contact the Elderly in Teddington (his family hosts an annual tea party for them) and Bristol renal unit (where they saved his brother-in-law’s life)

Saying: ‘What is going on inside their head?’ At home and at work, think about the underlying causes of anyone’s behaviour

Interests: Loves to ski, also surfing, cycling and running. He was a national gymnastics champion in New Zealand as a teenager.

Dear Colleagues,

Yesterday evening News Corporation announced its second quarter earnings for FY13.  Overall the company recorded healthy financial results for Q2 FY13, with revenue up 5% to $9.43 billion and adjusted operating income up 5% to $1.66 billion.

As regards our part of the business, News Corporation highlighted overall improvement in the publishing sector, with “increased contributions from the U.K. newspapers which benefited from the launch of the Sunday edition of The Sun in February 2012.”

Commenting on the results, Rupert Murdoch said:


"News Corporation’s fiscal second quarter performance reflects our strong momentum. Double-digit gains in our Cable and Television businesses, along with improvements in our Publishing segment, drove revenue and earnings growth even as we seized opportunities to invest in our core businesses for long- term and sustainable growth.

“The strategies we executed against in the quarter continue to bolster News Corporation's competitive position and enhance our ability to benefit from global demand for content, especially sports programming. As we make progress toward the proposed separation of our entertainment and publishing businesses later this year, I am confident in the future prospects for both businesses.”


With the UK 4th Quarter GDP at -0.3%, it is clear that we are still negotiating a fragile economic environment.  Regardless of whether or not we can escape a triple dip recession next quarter, it is reasonable for the country to expect a muted recovery for some time.

Despite this challenging context, you will have seen from our successful acquisition of the Barclays Premier League internet and mobile clips rights that we are not afraid to invest in areas that most directly support our world-class journalism and that can transform the experience we offer our subscribers.

We have an exciting few months ahead with the upcoming business split in the summer and the formation of the proposed new News Corporation.  There will doubtless be challenges to overcome and opportunities for us to seize, and I welcome your input as we work together to secure the long-term success of our titles.

Warm regards,

DIRECTING Guest directors at The Times Cheltenham Science Festival (from left) Dara O'Briain, Dame Wendy Hall and David Willetts

The line-up for this year’s The Times Cheltenham Science Festival on June 4-9 has been unveiled.

Called the country’s “premier science festival” by Prof Brian Cox, Cheltenham is a feast of hands-on adventures, exciting debate and inspiring events for all ages.

From asking what makes the world turn, to seeking out the secrets of the perfect cuppa, the science festival is all about asking questions – and this year’s programme features some of the world’s most outstanding thinkers exploring the biggest questions in science.

Guest directors entertainer Dara O'Briain, Professor of Computer Science Dame Wendy Hall and Minister for Science and Universities David Willetts have each added a generous dose of their own ideas and enthusiasm to the line-up.

Dara will interview physicist Peter Higgs and bring BBC2’s Science Club to Cheltenham, Wendy will explore how the web is changing society and David will examine the challenges facing science and technology in the UK.

Visitors can delve into the discovery of DNA with James Watson, examine the hunt for the Higgs boson with the man who started it all, Peter Higgs, and take a trip to the stars with pulsar expert Jocelyn Bell-Burnell.

Festival-goers can explore the health of the monarchy with BBC2’s Lucy Worsley, ask if an Act of Parliament can cure cancer with Maurice Saatchi and see a body scan live with Michael Mosley.

Visitors will also be able to get hands-on with the latest technology, explore the criminal mind and Shakespeare’s medicine cabinet, investigate exoplanets, meet winged predators and sniffer dogs and discover the science of tea. Audiences will learn about disturbed sleep, stem cells, fly-sized spies, comets and how to survive a tsunami.

Festival director Prof Mark Lythgoe is thrilled by this year’s line-up. He said: “We’ll be hosting some of our most inspiring and explosive events yet. We’ll be exploring some of the last century’s landmark scientific discoveries with big scientific thinkers, and looking to the future with a focus on cutting-edge research.”

The Medical Research Council, in partnership with The Times and Cheltenham Science Festival, are also on a hunt for the nation’s most significant medical innovation.
 
•  Members’ booking opens on Monday April 15 before public booking starts a week later.

Learning and Development trainer Laura Flaherty explains why she supports Amnesty International and Centrepoint through the Give As You Earn Scheme.

"I support Amnesty International and Centrepoint charities and am considering supporting a third one in the very near future. 

Amnesty International is a campaigning organisation that stands up for Human Rights all over the world. Their two main ways of achieving this are promoting awareness and opposing specific abuses of human rights i.e. wrongful imprisonment.

Centrepoint is a UK based charitable organisation focusing on supporting and rehabilitating homeless young people by offering housing, support and access to education; this is with a view to making sure that these young people have a future.

I chose these two charities because I feel strongly that people should have opportunities to succeed in life and be independent, regardless of their background and associated challenges; which much of the time are outside of their control.  Also, since joining NI I have become particularly inspired by and identify closely with the widely shared belief that social injustice should not go unreported or unchallenged and that we should all seek to protect those who are vulnerable to this for whatever reason."

Message from Gareth Wright, Head of Infrastructure & Enterprise Operations


Dear Colleagues,

We are excited to announce that Google+ is now available for all NI staff.

Click here to see a short video explaining more about Google+ at NI and how it can help you.

What is Google+?
A new social networking platform from Google with 343 million active users globally.

How do I access Google+?
  • Google+ is easily accessible through your email - just click on the +You link, located in the top left corner of your screen in Gmail
  • Step-by-step instructions on how to sign up are available here
How could I benefit from using Google+?

Simply put, with Google+ you can quickly and easily communicate and collaborate with others.  For example:
  • Share and discuss ideas
  • Keep up to date on projects
  • Request help from colleagues
  • Follow colleagues of interest
What are the main benefits of using Google+?
  • Participate in up to 15-person video conferences called ‘Hangouts’ - simply select this option when creating any calendar invite
  • Create bespoke ‘Circles’ of colleagues you can share information with - these can be groups of people involved in projects relevant just to you
Tell me more about ‘Circles’...
  • Circles are the key to sharing in Google+
  • Group your Google+ contacts into Circles that are relevant to you and share information to just those circles
Tell me more about ‘Communities’...
  • Communities give groups of people the perfect space to run projects and set up working groups
  • You can upload document links, photos and videos, and use Communities to coordinate events and meetings
  • Colleagues can browse and request to join established Communities or be added directly by the owner
Tell me more about ‘Hangouts’...
  • Hangouts are 15-participant video conferences
  • We anticipate a large uptake in these and parts of the business are already receiving Hangout invites instead of conference calls and Webex - Hangouts are free and don’t need to be booked
  • Aside from simple video conferencing, Hangouts can be used to collaborate in documents or share a screen
How is Google+ useful beyond NI?
Our customers, partners and competitors are increasingly embracing social media.  Use of Google+ at NI could allow us to exploit this social shift:
  • See what topics are trending in real-time and report otherwise untold stories
  • Target specific groups of readers (Circles) with tailored news that’s worth paying for
  • Live Blogging during elections, sports and showbiz events
  • Web-chats with special guests
  • Broadcast breaking news and interviews via Hangouts-on-Air - these are live video streams that any Google+ user can view
  • Reach new customers
How does Google+ fit in with Twitter or Facebook?
Google+ is a major platform in the social space with lots of existing and prospective customers using it.  At present we don’t see it a direct replacement to Twitter or Facebook but as an additional channel.

More information on Google+ at NI, including how to order webcams and headsets for Hangouts, can be found here.

Your use of Google+ is subject to News International's Acceptable Usage Policy and News Corporation's Electronic Communications Policy.  In addition, please take a moment to read the recommended Do's and Don'ts of Google+.

If you have any questions about Google+, please contact servicedesk@newsint.co.uk.


Regards,

Gareth Wright


Head of Infrastructure & Enterprise Operations

The Scottish Sun landed three coveted gongs last night at the 34th Scottish Press Awards.

The paper scooped Front Page of the Year for its dramatic take on the death of Rangers. Bold writer Bill Leckie landed Columnist of the Year. And talented Niamh Anderson was crowned Young Journalist of the Year.

The title was also just pipped to the top spot in three other categories at the prestigious Glasgow ceremony.

Gail Cameron was voted runner-up in Reporter of the Year, snapper Roddy Scott was second in News Photographer of the Year and our rival-crushing coverage of the Gers crisis bagged us the No2 slot in Team of the Year.

Last night Editor Andrew Harries said: “I’m very proud of all our winners, runners-up and nominees.
